metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: The History of Numbers
To understand AI, it is important to understand the concept of Numbers and Counting.
content.html: To understand AI, it is important to understand the concept of Numbers and Counting.

content.text: AI is About Numbers
Artificial Intelligence is all about Numbers .
content.html: Artificial Intelligence is all about Numbers.

content.text: Numbers are easy to understand: 1,2,3,4,5 ... 11,12,13,14,15.
content.html: Numbers are easy to understand: 1,2,3,4,5 ... 11,12,13,14,15.

content.text: Studies of animals indicates that even animals can understand some numbers:
content.html: Studies of animals indicates that even animals can understand some numbers:

content.text: The need for numbers in the modern world is absolute. We cannot live without numbers:
content.html: The need for numbers in the modern world is absolute. We cannot live without numbers:

content.text: AI is About Counting
The concept of numbers leads to the concept of counting.
content.html: The concept of numbers leads to the concept of counting.

content.text: Imagine prehistoric thinking:
content.html: Imagine prehistoric thinking:

content.text: Artificial Intelligence is a result of the human need for calculations.
content.html: Artificial Intelligence is a result of the human need for calculations.

content.text: Counting is easy to understand: 2 + 2 = 4.
content.html: Counting is easy to understand: 2 + 2 = 4.

content.text: Studies of animals indicates that animals can only understand very simple counting.
content.html: Studies of animals indicates that animals can only understand very simple counting.

content.text: How do Homo Sapiens deal with calculations?
content.html: How do Homo Sapiens deal with calculations?

content.text: Complex calculations are done by computers.
content.html: Complex calculations are done by computers.

content.text: "Yes! Computers can be smarter than humans."
content.html: "Yes! Computers can be smarter than humans."

content.text: Babylonian Numbers (Base 60)
We believe that the Babylonians started the development of complex counting.
content.html: We believe that the Babylonians started the development of complex counting.

content.text: The Babylonian number system has 60 different digits. It is a Base 60 system.
content.html: The Babylonian number system has 60 different digits. It is a Base 60 system.

content.text: Two Babylonian Scientists
About 6000 Years ago ...
content.html: About 6000 Years ago ...

content.text: Two Babylonian scientists were talking (writing numbers as dots on a paper):
content.html: Two Babylonian scientists were talking (writing numbers as dots on a paper):

content.text: Scientist 1: "We need to invent a number system".
content.html: Scientist 1: "We need to invent a number system".

content.text: Scientist 2: "What?".
content.html: Scientist 2: "What?".

content.text: Scientist 1: "We need to give every number a name".
content.html: Scientist 1: "We need to give every number a name".

content.text: Scientist 2: "You mean like 1, 2, and 3".
content.html: Scientist 2: "You mean like 1, 2, and 3".

content.text: Scientist 1: "Exactly!".
content.html: Scientist 1: "Exactly!".

content.text: Scientist 2: "But why?".
content.html: Scientist 2: "But why?".

content.text: Scientist 1: "How can I tell you I have 7 sons, if you don't know what 7 is?
content.html: Scientist 1: "How can I tell you I have 7 sons, if you don't know what 7 is?

content.text: Scientist 2: "Every number should have a name?".
content.html: Scientist 2: "Every number should have a name?".

content.text: Scientist 1: "Exactly!".
content.html: Scientist 1: "Exactly!".

content.text: Scientist 2: "So, how many numbers do we need? 15?".
content.html: Scientist 2: "So, how many numbers do we need? 15?".

content.text: Scientist 1: "More. Some people have more than 15 sons".
content.html: Scientist 1: "More. Some people have more than 15 sons".

content.text: Scientist 2: "Ok. 30 then. Just to be sure".
content.html: Scientist 2: "Ok. 30 then. Just to be sure".

content.text: Scientist 1: "But people older than 30 should be able to tell their age".
content.html: Scientist 1: "But people older than 30 should be able to tell their age".

content.text: Scientist 2: "Ok. 60 then".
content.html: Scientist 2: "Ok. 60 then".

content.text: Sexagesimal (base 60)
The sexagesimal system (base 60):
content.html: The sexagesimal system (base 60):

content.text: 60 is very versatile. It can be divided by 1,2,3,4,5,6,10,12,15,30, and 60.
content.html: 60 is very versatile. It can be divided by 1,2,3,4,5,6,10,12,15,30, and 60.

content.text: The Babylonian system was a place-value system, where the digits to the left represented full values, much like our decimal system.
content.html: The Babylonian system was a place-value system, where the digits to the left represented full values, much like our decimal system.

content.text: 1,5 means 65 (1 times 60, plus 5) 3,30 means 210 (3 times 60, plus 30)
content.html:
1,5 means 65 (1 times 60, plus 5)
3,30 means 210 (3 times 60, plus 30)

content.text: The reason why the Babylonians used 60 as the base, was (we like to believe) that 60 is divisible with most numbers: 1,2,3,4,5,6,10,12,15,20,30, and 60.
content.html: The reason why the Babylonians used 60 as the base, was (we like to believe) that 60 is divisible with most numbers: 1,2,3,4,5,6,10,12,15,20,30, and 60.

content.text: The downside was that the user had to remember 60 different digits. But the system was smart. A lot of it is still in use today:
content.html: The downside was that the user had to remember 60 different digits. But the system was smart. A lot of it is still in use today:

content.text: The Babylonians counted to 360 because of their sexagesimal (base-60) number system, which they inherited from earlier Mesopotamian cultures. This system led to many mathematical and astronomical conventions that we still use today, including:
content.html: The Babylonians counted to 360 because of their sexagesimal (base-60) number system, which they inherited from earlier Mesopotamian cultures. This system led to many mathematical and astronomical conventions that we still use today, including:

content.text: Dividing a circle into 360 degrees
Using Base-60 (Sexagesimal) System
Astronomical and Calendar Significance
Influence on Time Measurement
The origin of the Sexagesimal system (base 60) has been lost in history.
content.html: The origin of the Sexagesimal system (base 60) has been lost in history.

content.text: But it looks like it has been used in parallel with the Dozenal system since ancient times.
content.html: But it looks like it has been used in parallel with the Dozenal system since ancient times.

content.text: Dozenal (base 12)
The dozenal system (base 12):
content.html: The dozenal system (base 12):

content.text: 12 is very versatile. It can be divided by 1,2,3,4,6,and 12.
content.html: 12 is very versatile. It can be divided by 1,2,3,4,6,and 12.

content.text: How to Count Dozenal
With two hands, you can count to 60.
content.html: With two hands, you can count to 60.

content.text: Each of your fingers have 3 joints:
content.html: Each of your fingers have 3 joints:

content.text: Roman Numbers (Base 10)
Roman numbers originated in Rome and was used in Europe into the Middle Ages.
content.html: Roman numbers originated in Rome and was used in Europe into the Middle Ages.

content.text: The Romans used a Base 10 system. Possibly because they used their 10 fingers to count.
content.html: The Romans used a Base 10 system. Possibly because they used their 10 fingers to count.

content.text: Today, most of the world use a Base 10 number system: Western numbers, Chinese numbers, Brahmi numbers, Greek numbers, Hebrew numbers...
content.html:
Today, most of the world use a Base 10 number system:
Western numbers, Chinese numbers, Brahmi numbers, Greek numbers, Hebrew numbers...

content.text: 5 means 5 50 means 5 times 10 500 means 5 times 100 57 means 5 times 10, plus 7 75 means 7 times 10, plus 5
content.html:
5 means 5
50 means 5 times 10
500 means 5 times 100

57 means 5 times 10, plus 7
75 means 7 times 10, plus 5

content.text: Digital Numbers (Base 2)
Humans can count with base 10 numbers, computers can not.
content.html: Humans can count with base 10 numbers, computers can not.

content.text: Electricity cannot count. Electricity can only be On and Off.
content.html: Electricity cannot count. Electricity can only be On and Off.

content.text: Computers use Electricity or Magnetism to represent On and Off.
content.html: Computers use Electricity or Magnetism to represent On and Off.

content.text: Computers use Digital Numbers like 11100110 (in contrast to Base 10 Numbers like 230).
content.html: Computers use Digital Numbers like 11100110 (in contrast to Base 10 Numbers like 230).

content.text: Digital numbers (11100110) are also called Binary Numbers .
content.html: Digital numbers (11100110) are also called Binary Numbers.

content.text: You will learn more about digital computers in the next chapter.
content.html: You will learn more about digital computers in the next chapter.

content.text: Man vs. Computer
Computers can handle an unlimited amount of numbers.
content.html: Computers can handle an unlimited amount of numbers.

content.text: Humans can not.
content.html: Humans can not.
